skill.name: dependency-upgrade
skill.description: Manage major dependency version upgrades with compatibility analysis, staged rollout, and comprehensive testing. Use when upgrading framework versions, updating major dependencies, or managing breaking changes in libraries.
skill.summary: Manage major dependency version upgrades with compatibility analysis and staged rollout
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill provides documentation and guidance for dependency management workflows. All static findings are false positives: the external commands are example bash/npm commands in documentation, filesystem operations are example migration scripts, and weak crypto detections are from the word 'MD5' in version strings. The skill contains no executable code and poses no security risk.

low_findings.title: Documentation Contains Command Examples
low_findings.description: The SKILL.md file contains numerous example bash commands for dependency management (npm, yarn, git). These are educational examples showing proper dependency upgrade workflows, not executable code. Users must manually execute these commands in their own environments.

content.user_title: Upgrade Dependencies with Confidence and Testing
content.value_statement: Managing major dependency upgrades is risky without proper planning and testing. This skill guides you through compatibility analysis, staged rollout strategies, and comprehensive testing to safely upgrade frameworks and libraries without breaking your application.
actual_capabilities: Provide semantic versioning review and best practices for dependency management
Guide dependency analysis using npm and yarn audit tools
Offer staged upgrade strategies with incremental testing between each step
Supply compatibility matrix examples for common framework combinations
Include automated testing patterns for unit, integration, and E2E validation
Demonstrate rollback plans and safe upgrade procedures
limitations: Does not automatically execute upgrades or modify package files
Requires manual review of changelogs and breaking changes for specific packages
Cannot predict all runtime issues that may occur after upgrades
Examples focus primarily on JavaScript ecosystem (npm, yarn)

use_cases.title: Framework Version Upgrade
use_cases.description: A developer needs to upgrade React from version 16 to 18 while ensuring all peer dependencies remain compatible and no breaking changes affect the application.

use_cases.title: Security Vulnerability Remediation
use_cases.description: A development team must update dependencies flagged by npm audit, requiring careful analysis of which packages can be safely upgraded without introducing regressions.

use_cases.title: Legacy Modernization
use_cases.description: A team maintaining an older codebase wants to systematically upgrade outdated dependencies using incremental testing and automated tools like Renovate or Dependabot.

best_practices: Upgrade dependencies incrementally, one major version at a time, running full test suites after each upgrade to isolate issues
Always read changelogs and migration guides before upgrading to understand breaking changes and required code modifications
Use lock files and automated tools like Renovate or Dependabot to maintain dependencies while keeping control over major version changes
anti_patterns: Upgrading all dependencies at once without testing between each change makes it impossible to identify which upgrade caused failures
Ignoring peer dependency warnings or using --force flags without understanding compatibility issues can lead to runtime errors
Skipping major versions in an attempt to save time often results in accumulated breaking changes that are harder to resolve

faq.question: Should I upgrade all outdated dependencies at once?
faq.answer: No, upgrade incrementally starting with security patches, then one major dependency at a time. Test thoroughly after each upgrade to isolate any issues.

faq.question: What does the caret symbol mean in package versions?
faq.answer: The caret (^) allows minor and patch updates but not major versions. For example, ^2.3.1 allows versions from 2.3.1 up to but not including 3.0.0.

faq.question: How do I handle peer dependency conflicts?
faq.answer: First check if newer versions are compatible. If not, you may need to upgrade or downgrade related packages together, or use resolutions in package.json to force specific versions.

faq.question: What is the difference between npm update and npm install?
faq.answer: npm update respects semver ranges in package.json and updates within those constraints. npm install with a version argument changes package.json to the exact version specified.

faq.question: How can I automate dependency updates safely?
faq.answer: Use tools like Renovate or Dependabot configured to auto-merge patch and minor updates while requiring manual review for major versions. Always require passing tests before merging.

faq.question: What should I do if tests fail after a dependency upgrade?
faq.answer: Roll back the upgrade, review the changelog for breaking changes, update your code to match the new API, then attempt the upgrade again. Consider upgrading one major version at a time.
